Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery heavy chalice with handle root on left; white slip; interior glazed black; painted decoration of dancing komast in added white (figure kneeling to left with an added yellow wreath on his chest and added red knee-caps outlined in yellow); below, traces of two white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of lower part of female figure to right, wearing a chiton with dilute lines and a black himation with red dots and a border of brown dots with red centres between dilute lines; feet in outline; below the figure, two dilute lines; handle zone reserved with trace of black on handle root; below, dark brown band above red area.
Curator's comments: Lemos takes the figure on the interior as a komast playing the aulos flute and attributes the sherd to the Aphaia Painter. The painter and the group are named after the chalice found in the sanctuary of Aphaia on Aegina, and vessels from this group display a thematic unity; all have figures in garments and, in their particular preserved state, the lower parts of chitons and himatia. None of the group have any filling ornament and the interior decoration of some of the vessels consists of komasts rendered in the light on dark technique. Williams argues that the interior images portrayed on the chalices were perhaps representations of komos activities that took place in Chios. The buttock pads exaggerated the dancers’ bottoms. The sakkos worn by many of these komasts as well as the earrings suggest the dancers, who were male, were practicing a form of transvestism. If so, these Chians dancers were precursors of the magodoi or performers who wore women’s clothing, made lewd gestures and performed as female and drunk characters. The gestures of the dancers on the chalices are limited and consist of holding pomegranates, tambourines (or wreaths) and snapping fingers. Such dances may also have been connected to religious festivals and performed after religious feasts. Williams, 1983, 162-3 See also Boardman, J., Excavations in Chios 1952-1955. Greek Emporio. Annual of the British School at Athens Supplement 6. Oxford 1967, 169, note 9. For parallels, see Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983, 159 (figs 3 and 4). The thickness of the sherd suggests that the vase was a heavy chalice.
